Toby Meyjes for Metro.co.uk Sunday 26 Feb 2017 6:29 pm Crowds gather for the free screening of Asghar Farhadiâ€™s The Salesman in Trafalgar Square (Picture: Jonathan Brady/PA Wire) 
Thousands of people have attended a screening of The Salesman in Trafalgar Square ahead of the Oscars ceremony its director boycotted. 
The screening of the film was scheduled by London Mayor Sadiq Khan after Asghar Farhadi announced he would boycott the ceremony in the wake of Trumpâ€™s travel ban. Couple traumatised after hospital accidentally cremates baby 
Under the controversial order the Iranian would have been unable to travel to the United States, so he and the filmâ€™s lead actress, Taraneh Alidoosti, said they would not attend the Academy Awards in Los Angeles. 
The free event was held in Trafalgar Square, for which the director was not present, but instead sent a recorded message for the crowd. 
He said: â€˜Despite our different religions, cultures and nationalities, we are all citizens of the world. Thousands attended the screening ahead of the Oscars tonight (Picture: Jonathan Brady/PA Wire) Lily Cole was amongst those to address the crowd (Picture: Jonathan Brady/PA Wire) Sadiq Khan said the screening would send the message London Is Open (Picture: Jonathan Brady/PA Wire) Crowds gathered for the free screening (Picture: Jonathan Brady/PA Wire) 
He apologised for not being at the event in person, and added: â€˜However, I am there in spirit and I thank you all from the bottom of my heart.â€™ 
Also present was model Lily Cole who said the travel ban was â€˜unnecessary in this day and ageâ€™. 
She said: â€˜We are here to say what alternatives are possible, we are here to demonstrate that alternatives are possible and why things like the Trump ban are unnecessary in this day and age, because London is wonderfully open. 
â€˜I hope you remember the pretext that brought us here, because we may see more ludicrous policies coming out, we may see more attempts to discriminate against millions of people based purely on their race and where they were born.

Others to address the audience included singer Damon Albarn and Mariella Frostrup.

He said afterwards: â€˜There are people here from Iran to Iraq, from Shoreditch and Streatham, from Lebanon and London â€“ showing the world that London is open. Open to talent, open to creativity and open to people. 
â€˜At a time when people want to have travel bans, we should talk about welcoming people. At a time when people want to build walls, we should build bridges. 
â€˜At a time when people are dividing communities, I want to unite communities.
